raw_text:
Israel looks to US for bank chief
 
 Israel has asked a US banker and former International Monetary Fund director to run its central bank.
 
 Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of banking giant Citigroup, has agreed to take the Bank of Israel job subject to approval from parliament and cabinet. His nomination by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon came as a surprise, and led to gains on the Tel Aviv stock market. Mr Fischer, who speaks fluent Hebrew, will have to become an Israeli citizen to take the job. The US says he will not have to give up US citizenship to do so.
 
 Previous incumbent David Klein, who often argued with the Finance Ministry, steps down on 16 January. Mr Fischer will face a delicate balancing act - both in political and economic terms - between Mr Sharon and finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who also backed his nomination. But his appointment has also raised hopes that it could bring in fresh investment - and perhaps even an improvement in the country's credit rating Mr Fischer first went to Israel for six months in 1973, and almost emigrated there before deciding finally to return to the US. While teaching at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology he spent a month seconded to the Bank of Israel in 1979, beginning a long-time involvement in studying Israel's economy. In 1983 Mr Fischer became adviser on Israel's economy to then-US secretary of state George Shultz. At the World Bank in 1985, he participated in drawing up an economic stabilisation package for Israel.
llama3.2:1b: Israel has appointed Stanley Fischer, former director of the International Monetary Fund, as its new central bank chief, subject to parliamentary and cabinet approval. He will become a US citizen but must give up his citizenship if he leaves. Fischer will face balancing acts between Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Finance Minister Binyamin Netanyahu over economic policies and credit rating.
llama3.2:3b: Israel has asked Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of Citigroup and former IMF director, to head its central bank subject to parliament approval. He will need to become an Israeli citizen and is backed by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Finance Minister Binyamin Netanyahu. Fischer's appointment may bring in fresh investment and improve the country's credit rating, following David Klein's departure on January 16th.
gemma2:2b: Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon appointed Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of Citigroup, as the new head of the Bank of Israel. Fischer will require Israeli citizenship to take the job after becoming a subject of parliament and cabinet approval. This appointment marks a change from David Klein who is stepping down on January 16th. Fischer's experience with Israel's economy, including past involvement at the World Bank, positions him to navigate delicate political and economic considerations within the country.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Israel is seeking a US central bank chief after former Citigroup vice chairman Stanley Fischer agreed to run it with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon as an interim measure while he becomes an Israeli citizen.
The US has long sought to appoint Fischer but faces opposition from the government and Netanyahu, whose approval would be necessary for him to take office. His appointment could have a positive impact on Israel's economy by increasing investment and improving its credit rating.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Israel has appointed Stanley Fischer as its new central bank governor, a US banker and former IMF director who will oversee the country's monetary policy while facing political pressures from Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Finance Minister Binyamin Netanyahu.
qwen2.5:3b: Israel has appointed former US banker and International Monetary Fund director Stanley Fischer as its central bank chief after his nomination by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. Subject to parliamentary and cabinet approval, Fischer will take the position if approved. Fluent in Hebrew, he must become an Israeli citizen. The appointment comes after David Klein resigned on January 16th and is expected to bring fresh investment and potentially improve Israel's credit rating. Fischer spent time at the Bank of Israel earlier in his career and has advised both the US government and World Bank on Israel's economy.
opencoder:1.5b:
Israel looks to US for bank chief, US asks banker and former International Monetary Fund director to run its central bank.

Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of banking giant Citigroup agrees to take the Bank of Israel job subject to approval from parliament and cabinet.

The US nominates Mr Fischer as a surprise nominee to the Bank of Israel's position. He has also attracted gains on the Tel Aviv stock market and has announced an appointment with Ariel Sharon.

Mr Fischer, who is fluent in Hebrew, will need to become an Israeli citizen to take his job.

His appointment comes with a delicate balancing act between Mr Sharon and finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who backed his nomination. While both sides argue about the future of the job, the former is more supportive - he believes that it could bring fresh investment and perhaps even an improvement in the country's credit rating.

In 1973, Mr Fischer traveled to Israel for six months before deciding to return to the US. Despite his political stance, his employment as a bank chief was finalised by David Klein, a former Finance Minister who frequently argued with the Bank of Israel. It is noted that the US also spent a month seconded to the Bank of Israel in 1979, and has been involved in studying Israel's economy since then.

In 1983, Mr Fischer became adviser on Israel's economy to then-US Secretary of State George Shultz. While at the World Bank, he participated in drawing up an economic stabilisation package for Israel, contributing significantly to the country’s future development.

Israel looks to US for bank chief

His nomination by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon came as a surprise, and led to gains on the Tel Aviv stock market. Mr Fischer, who speaks fluent Hebrew, will have to become an Israeli citizen to take the job. The US says he will not have to give up US citizenship to do so.

Previous incumbent David Klein has stepped down on 16 January. Mr Fischer will face a delicate balancing act - both in political and economic terms - between Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who also backed his nomination. But his appointment has also raised hopes that it could bring in fresh investment - and perhaps even an improvement in the country's credit rating Mr Fischer first went to Israel for six months in 1973, and almost emigrated there before deciding finally to return to the US. While teaching at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology he spent a month seconded to the Bank of Israel in 1979, beginning a long-time involvement in studying Israel's economy. In 1983 Mr Fischer became adviser on Israel's economy to then-US secretary of state George Shultz. At the World Bank in 1985, he participated in drawing up an economic stabilisation package for Israel.

<think>
Alright, let me try to figure out how to approach this user's query. They want a summary of a given text, preserving key ideas and details. The output should be plain text without any explanations or formatting.

First, I'll read through the provided text carefully. It seems to be about the appointment of Stanley Fischer as Bank of Israel's bank chief by the US. There are several important points: Fischer is being nominated for a position in a major bank that's been involved with the Fed. He was previously an advisor at the World Bank, has experience in teaching economics, and he returned to the US after leaving Israel.

I'll make sure to mention his history in teaching economics at MIT and Massachusettts Institute of Technology where he was seconded there. Also, I should note that Fischer went to Israel for six months before deciding to leave.

Israel has announced a bid for US Bank of Canada's bank chief position, with former International Monetary Fund director Stanley Fischer under the prime minister's scrutiny. Fischer will join the Bank of Israel if his nomination is approved by parliament and cabinet. He will become an Israeli citizen upon taking the role, but the US allows him to remain American. Fischer was previously a principal advisor at the World Bank and has experience in teaching economics. He returned to the US after leaving Israel for six months, where he was seconded to the Bank of Israel in 1979. Fischer joined the World Bank in 1983 as an economic analyst, became a World Economic Forum member in 1984, and later served as advisor on Israel's economy under US Secretary of State George Shultz at the World Bank in 1985.
tinyllama:1.1b: Israel has appointed Stanley Fischer as its new central bank chief, subject to approval from parliament and cabinet. Mr Fischer will take over after David Klein stepped down on January 16th, following political protests from the Finance Ministry. Banking giant Citigroup's vice chairman, who speaks fluently Hebrew, will have to become an Israeli citizen in order to take the job. As part of his selection process, Mr Fischer has faced opposition, particularly from Finance Minister Binyaim Netanyahu, who also supported his nomination. The appointment has raised hopes for fresh investment and improvement in Israel's credit rating, while Mr Fischer has spent almost 20 years studying the country's economy. Born in Austria and educated at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the World Bank, he began his career as a consultant to the Bank of Israel and then worked for several months in Tel Aviv before being seconded there by the US Federal Reserve in 1973. He spent a month with the Bank of Israel in 1983 and later became an adviser on Israeli economics to former US Secretary of State George Shultz.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summarization: Israel is considering appointing a US banker, Stanley Fischer, as its new central bank chief, seeking to bring fresh investment and improve credit rating. The appointment was initially opposed by Israeli finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu but approved by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon following a surprising request from the Bank of Israel.

Mr Fischer will have to become an Israeli citizen to take the job but his appointment has also raised concerns about a delicate balancing act between him and finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who supports his nomination.

hermes3:3b: Israel seeks US banker Stanley Fischer as Bank of Israel chief.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Israel has tapped Stanley Fischer, a US banker and former IMF director, to lead its central bank. Fischer, currently Citigroup's vice chairman, agreed to the position contingent on parliamentary and cabinet approval. His nomination by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was unexpected, causing a positive reaction in Tel Aviv's stock market. To accept, Fischer must become an Israeli citizen, although the US assures him it won't require relinquishing his US citizenship.

Fischer, who speaks Hebrew fluently and has extensive experience with Israel's economy due to past academic appointments and advisory roles at the World Bank and under former US Secretary of State George Shultz, will need to navigate political dynamics between Prime Minister Sharon and Finance Minister Binyamin Netanyahu. His appointment is seen as potentially bringing in foreign investment and improving Israel's credit rating. Fischer previously spent time in Israel as a teacher at MIT, during which he served as an adviser on its economy to Shultz in 1979.
reference: Mr Fischer will face a delicate balancing act - both in political and economic terms - between Mr Sharon and finance minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who also backed his nomination.But his appointment has also raised hopes that it could bring in fresh investment - and perhaps even an improvement in the country's credit rating Mr Fischer first went to Israel for six months in 1973, and almost emigrated there before deciding finally to return to the US.Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of banking giant Citigroup, has agreed to take the Bank of Israel job subject to approval from parliament and cabinet.Israel has asked a US banker and former International Monetary Fund director to run its central bank.Mr Fischer, who speaks fluent Hebrew, will have to become an Israeli citizen to take the job.
